BiblioData.Title: SILICA MAGNETIC PARTICLES WITH A HIGH NUCLEIC ACID BINDING CAPABILITY
BiblioData.Abstract: Magnetic particles for nucleic acid isolation are coated with silica and separated from impurities and nanoparticulates using a multi-step fractionation process. In each cycle of the fractionation process, the particles are stirred, sedimented, and resuspended, resulting in a decline in pH of the suspended particles. Repeating the fractionation process until the resuspended particles have dropped to a target pH in the range of about 9 to 10.5, and their zeta potential is more negative than about -40 mV, results in a purified population of particles with a high and reproducible binding capacity for nucleic acids. The silica-treated magnetic beads produced by the method offer improved sensitivity and consistency for recovery of nucleic acids in a sample.

Claims.P: CLAIMS What is claimed is:
1. A composition comprising silica-coated magnetic particles produced by a process comprising the steps of:
(a) reacting magnetic particles with waterglass;
(b) sedimenting the particles;
(c) resuspending the sedimented particles to form an aqueous suspension; and (d) repeating steps (b) and (c) until the pH of the aqueous suspension is in the range from about pH 9.4 to about pH 10.0.
2. The composition of claim 1, wherein 5 to 15 cycles of sedimenting and resuspending the particles are performed.
3. The composition of claim 1, wherein the final particle suspension comprises a buffer.
4. The composition of claim 3, wherein the buffer is 2- cyclohexylaminoethane-sulphonic acid.
5. The composition of claim 3, wherein the pH of the final particle suspension is about 9.5 to about 9.9.
6. The composition of claim 5, wherein the pH of the final particle suspension is about 9.7.
7. The composition of claim 1, wherein the pH of the suspension of magnetic particles in waterglass solution formed in step (a) has an initial pH of about 10 to about 13.
8. The composition of claim 1, wherein the zeta potential at pH 7 of the particles is more negative than -40 mv.
9. The composition of claim 8, wherein the zeta potential at pH 7 is in the range of about -48 to about -58 mV.
10. The composition of claim 1, wherein the isoelectric point of the particles is in the range of pH 2.7 to pH 2.8.
11. The composition of claim 1, wherein the magnetic particles comprise F[theta]3[theta]4.

12. The composition of claim 11, wherein the magnetic particles consist of granular Fe3U4 having a particle size distribution characterized by a d50 value in the range of about 0.5 to about 1.5 [mu]m.
13. The composition of claim 12, wherein the magnetic particles consist of granular F[theta]3[theta]4 having a particle size distribution characterized by a d5o value of about 1 [mu]m.
14. The composition of claim 1, wherein at least 50% of the silica-coated particles have a diameter of less than 2 [mu]m.
15. The composition of claim 14, wherein at least 90% of the silica-coated particles have a diameter of less than 2 [mu]m.
16. The composition of claim 1, wherein the silica coating of the particles is less than about 1 nm in thickness.
17. The composition of claim 1, wherein the Si content of the silica-coated particles is in the range of about 6 to about 7 atomic percent.
18. The composition of claim 1, wherein the Fe/Si atomic ratio of the silica-coated particles is in the range of about 2 to about 2.5.
19. The composition of claim 1, wherein the silica-coated particles bind nucleic acid in a chaotrope solution.

20. The composition of claim 1, wherein the silica-coated particles have a saturation magnetism of about 80 to about 90 emu/g, a remanence flux density of about 5 to about 7 emu/g, and a coercivity value of about 50 to about 80 Oe.

21. The composition of claim 1, wherein the silica-coated particles are capable of recovering a PCR-detectable nucleic acid sequence present in a sample at a concentration from about 50 to about one million copies per ml.
22. A process of preparing silica-coated magnetic particles, the process comprising the steps of:
(a) reacting magnetic particles with waterglass;
(b) sedimenting the particles;
(c) resuspending the sedimented particles to form an aqueous suspension; and (d) repeating steps (b) and (c) until the pH of the aqueous suspension is in the range from about pH 9.4 to about pH 10.0.
23. The process of claim 22, wherein the final pH of the aqueous suspension is about 9.7.
24. The process of claim 22, wherein step of reacting is carried out for about 30 minutes at about 15 to 40<0>C.
25. The process of claim 22, wherein the step of sedimenting is performed by allowing the particles to settle without stirring at about 1 x g.
26. The process of claim 25, wherein the step of sedimenting is performed by allowing the particles to settle for about 1 hour.
27. The process of claim 22, wherein the step of sedimenting comprises the use of magnetism or centrifugation .
28. The process of claim 22, wherein the step of resuspending comprises stirring for at least 30 minutes.
29. The process of claim 22, further comprising the step of:
(e) suspending the silica-coated particles in a buffer at a pH in the range of about pH 9.5 to about pH 9.8.

30. The process of claim 22, wherein the silica-coated particles are subsequently analyzed for at least one characteristic selected from particle size distribution, Fe content, Si content, zeta potential, saturation magnetism, remanence flux density, and coercivity.
31. The process of claim 22, wherein the zeta potential at pH 7 of the particles is more negative than -40 mv.
32. The process of claim 31, wherein the zeta potential at pH 7 is in the range of about -48 to about -58 mV.
33. A method of analyzing a nucleic acid in a sample, comprising binding said nucleic acid to a suspension of silica-coated magnetic beads produced according to the process of claim 22.
34. A kit comprising a composition according to claim 1 and instructions for the use thereof in a method of isolating or analyzing a nucleic acid.
